titleStmt.title: Certamen Brittanicum, Gallico Hispanicum. A true relation of a conference holden between Charles Stuart King of Scots, Don Lewis de Haro, and the Cardinall Mazarine, the two grand favorites of the courts of France and Spaine. Wherein is touched something of the interests of the said states one to the other, and of both in relation to the said King of Scots. As also how much it hath been endeavoured to make him turn Catholike, with his constant resolution to live and dye in the true Protestant religion. Sent in a letter to the Prince of Conde, and by his secretary to a freind of private trust in England, who hath caused the same to be faithfuly rendred into English out of the Spanish copie.

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

div.p:
THE two State Favorites and grande Polititians of Europe Don Lewis de Haro and Cardinall Mazarine the two publike EmbaÅ¿Å¿adours for the Kings of Spaine and France to mannage the treaty of marriage between the Å¿aid King of France and the Infant of Spaine, having according to former reÅ¿olutions met on on the borders of both Kingdomes, after many nicetyes Å¿atisfied, objections reÅ¿olved, and Å¿everall ceremonious complements of reÅ¿pect paÅ¿t, they began to conÅ¿ult of thoÅ¿e things, the Å¿etling whereof was the foundation of their meeting: wherein among other things, it fell into conÅ¿ideration, who Å¿hould be included within the articles
of the peace to be concluded thereby and who debarred, amongÅ¿t whom the Cardinall deÅ¿ired that the King of Scots might be one in regard his MaÅ¿ter had (contrary to the Law of Nations, friendÅ¿hip and alliance) baniÅ¿hed him out of his Court and Kingdome: whereupon Don Lewis anÅ¿wered, there is the more reaÅ¿on he Å¿hould be taken in, for though his neereÅ¿t kindred, who had formerly been obliged to his Father, had forced him to retreate from among them, yet Å¿eeing he had caÅ¿t himÅ¿elfe upon his MaÅ¿ter, he Å¿hould finde he did not relye on a broken reede, which while he truÅ¿ted would run into his hand, but that he would be to him as CaÅ¿tle of defence, wherein he might Å¿helter him from the injurious Å¿tormes which undeÅ¿ervedly did threaten him, Å¿o that whether or no he be nominally admitted by you it much matters, Å¿ince he is an allye, a friend and confederate of my maÅ¿ters, all whoÅ¿e allyes muÅ¿t and Å¿hall be neceÅ¿Å¿arily included. Many dayes and much time being Å¿pent in theÅ¿e debates: and notice thereof being brought to the King of Scots, he thought it very convenient to goe to the place of meeting, and there to make his application to that noble perÅ¿on who had Å¿tood up Å¿o much for his intereÅ¿t, and having at laÅ¿t attained to the end of his journey, (hoping to Crowne this beginning of his deÅ¿ires with Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e) he went privately to the Lord Don Lewis, who though Å¿omewhat aÅ¿toniÅ¿hed at his Å¿udden and unexpected arrivall did yet nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e treate him with many extraordinary civilityes, the uÅ¿uall teÅ¿timonyes of a condiall affection, with promiÅ¿e in convenient time to procure a meeting between themÅ¿elves, and the Cardinall, in which they would conÅ¿ult what was neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and what was fit to be done, whereby he Å¿hould Å¿ee, that no Å¿tone Å¿hould
be unturned, if it might raiÅ¿e him an advantage or procure him an aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance, Å¿o as he on his part, would not Å¿tand in his own light, and run himÅ¿elfe into a Dilemma, with too much obÅ¿tinacy in Å¿ome particulars, at which time they parted with a reaÅ¿Å¿urance of a future meeting Å¿uddenly.

According to his promiÅ¿e about the midÅ¿t of September laÅ¿t paÅ¿t the SpaniÅ¿h Grandee gained a meeting: where they after Å¿ome reÅ¿pects (each reÅ¿erving to himÅ¿elfe his own Grandezza, Don Lewis began; there hath been, Sir, Å¿ome controverÅ¿y between the Cardinall his Eminency and my Å¿elfe about your intereÅ¿t, I judging it neceÅ¿Å¿ary that upon a concluÅ¿ion of a peace between two the moÅ¿t potent Princes of Europe, (a third being now diÅ¿treÅ¿Å¿ed through the malevolent diÅ¿poÅ¿itions of ill affected and rebellious Å¿ubjects Å¿hould not be left out, whereunto the Cardinall replyed, I confeÅ¿Å¿e it is a work of charity and piety, but where the intereÅ¿t of the Å¿tate whereof I am a Å¿ubject, cannot but Å¿uffer by Å¿uch a conceÅ¿Å¿ion, I muÅ¿t crave pardon: you know or at the leaÅ¿t have heard, how the King my MaÅ¿ter was compelled to make a peace with the EngliÅ¿h State, and upon what unequall term we gained the Å¿ame, he left many of his friends and kindred in the in the Lurch, and was glad to give Dunkirk and Å¿ome other places for the purchaÅ¿e therof. He was particularly bound to baniÅ¿h this noble perÅ¿on here preÅ¿ent and never to aide or aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿t him, but to take all perÅ¿ons, his friend, and allves to be our enemies, Å¿o that I cannot Å¿aluo honore regiae majeÅ¿tatis, conclude any thing as to that point.

And doth my CoÅ¿en truly (Å¿aid the King of Scots) Å¿o highly prize his Å¿o dearly bought peace: Å¿urely he cannot but know that the perÅ¿on with whom he made, it was no
better then a regicide, a perÅ¿on who waÅ¿hed his hands in the Å¿acred blood of his King, without any juÅ¿t or equall quarrell, for to him and his villanous retinew all things were lawfull that might any way Å¿erve their turn, all their actions and paÅ¿Å¿ions how diverÅ¿e and inconÅ¿tant Å¿oever were in their ambition Å¿wallowed up and thereinto converted, they forbeare no manner of murthers, breach of faith and buying other mens fidelity, they eÅ¿teeme as a vertue and think no place Å¿trong where an horÅ¿e laden with gold may enter, not any Citty or State unconquerable, where any of the greateÅ¿t hope to be made greater can looÅ¿e the Å¿enÅ¿e of other mens Å¿orrow and Å¿ubjection: pardon my deviation, he that Å¿peakes of his owne greifes, of his owne troubles Å¿peakes Å¿enÅ¿ible: Å¿uch then I Å¿ay, were the men your MaÅ¿ters men, Å¿ubjected himÅ¿elfe to: and I pray for what reaÅ¿on, why out of a Å¿pirit of revenge the one Å¿ought, the other did conclude a peace, the firÅ¿t to Å¿atisfie his deÅ¿ire on the Prince of Conde, the other that he might fulyll his cruelty towards me.

Truly Å¿aid Don Lewis and that poÅ¿Å¿ibly might be the deÅ¿igne of both; for I know the King of Spain was tampered with, to the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e and when by policy and undermining the effect could not be attained, then Å¿traight a war was included with Spaine, Jamarca Å¿eized on by violence, and Dunkirk with Å¿ome few other places Å¿tollen into by craft, but I really beleive, that if they Å¿hould take a veiw of their TreaÅ¿ury and but reckon the men thoÅ¿e inconÅ¿iderable places have coÅ¿t them, they would quickly find the blood and treaÅ¿ure hugely to over-ballance the worth thereof. For what advantage have they gotten thereby for Jamaica is Å¿o poore a place, that without continuall freÅ¿h Å¿upplyes the Å¿ouldyary and people there
muÅ¿t Å¿tarve, and then obÅ¿erve but the danger of bringing in proviÅ¿ion, the place being wholly invironed with IÅ¿lands under the King of Spaines dominion well fortified, well attended on by Å¿hips and populouÅ¿ly rich and the whole place will not countervaile either half the danger or charge. And as for Dunkirk which they boaÅ¿t is the key into Flanders, if they can make no better uÅ¿e thereof for the future, then they have hitherto done, it may poÅ¿Å¿ibly prove to them mors in olla, a thing of Å¿o hard a digeÅ¿tion that their greedy Å¿tomacks Å¿hall be forced to reÅ¿tore, let it be as it will, quoth the Cardinll, we Å¿hall endeavour to hold out own and neither meddle in the Å¿ettling or unÅ¿etling Common-wealths or Kingdomes.

'Tis well, anÅ¿wered the King of Scots, but you were I am Å¿ure of another minde when you were baniÅ¿hed out of France: but the wheele with you was quickly round, thanks to your policy, and Machiavellian principles: but as to the maine point for this is but beating about the buÅ¿h, my deÅ¿ire is that as in this happy treaty and concluÅ¿ion of a peace, and a marriage, moÅ¿t of the Princes, and Å¿tates of Europe will have a Å¿hare of happineÅ¿Å¿e, I alone may not be Å¿et aÅ¿ide: and I am very well aÅ¿Å¿ured, that if my condition (as being moÅ¿t wrongfully expulÅ¿ed out of my Fathers Kingdome and my lawfull inheritance) were but taken in among the reÅ¿t of your friends, the very Å¿enÅ¿e thereof would Å¿o move other neighbour Princes and Å¿tates, that they would Å¿uddenly turn their many promiÅ¿es into actions, and inÅ¿tead of words aide me with Swords.

I muÅ¿t deale ingeniouÅ¿ly with you, Å¿aid Don Lewis, it is the intent of my MaÅ¿ter to take you in as an Ally and Friend: and I am Å¿ure having him, you gaine the whole
houÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria, who by reaÅ¿on of their great power and Å¿way in the Empire, (as having the Emperor of their kindred) command the cheife and greateÅ¿t part of Europe: for by that meanes all the Catholike Princes there will be aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tant: and if you but weigh the alliance between theÅ¿e, the Dane, the Pole, and Å¿everall others, in the whole, it will be found that two third parts of Europe will all follow.

I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e replyed the Cardinall, you have Å¿aid much to the purpoÅ¿e, the Leagues and Alliances you have Å¿poken of are many and very Å¿trong, but moÅ¿t of them will find buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e enough to defend themÅ¿elves againÅ¿t the Swede and his partakers, for though by the new League they may Å¿eem Å¿orely to threaten him, yet he is able by HimÅ¿elfe and his Confederates (as he hath done Å¿ome years already) to find them imployment at home.

Indeed (retorted the King of Scots) I think your cheif hopes is on the King of Sweden, who if I be not miÅ¿taken, is in the League with your Eminencyes MaÅ¿ter, as alÅ¿o with my Enemies: but I hope (and Å¿omething I have of confidence to aÅ¿Å¿ure me thereof) that the MarqueÅ¿s of Brandenburgh (not to mention my CoÅ¿en of the Palatanate) who is late joyned with the Emperor and houÅ¿e of AuÅ¿tria, will Å¿o pull his fethers, that on a Å¿udden he Å¿hall not flye farre abroad.

It may be Å¿o (anÅ¿wered the Cardinall) but now admitting all your hopes to be certainties, they will little availe, for his HolineÅ¿Å¿e is not at all thought of : and with out all diÅ¿pute he will goe farre in Italy: 'tis true, Italy is divided into four parts, viz. Lumbardy, TuÅ¿cany, St. Peters Patrimony; and the Kingdome of Naples: In Lumbardy Å¿tand many rich Governments, as the Dukedome of Millayne (which is my MaÅ¿ters) of Mantua, of Florence, and

What then (anÅ¿wered Don Lewis) is not my MaÅ¿ter the eldeÅ¿t Å¿on of the Church? I am confident his HolineÅ¿s will as Å¿oon bend towards him as the greateÅ¿t. I muÅ¿t confeÅ¿Å¿e (anÅ¿wered the King of Scots) I would very willingly be reinÅ¿tated in my Kingdomes and would even give, forgive, grant or doe any thing even beyond expectation to be hoped from me to come to that happyneÅ¿Å¿e, but to Å¿eek or gain them, and to looÅ¿e or hazard my hopes of Heaven, I dare not, I cannot, for I Å¿hall Å¿ooner chooÅ¿e to dye an exile from my native Country then to baniÅ¿h or change the Religion I have been bred and born in for a Å¿ettlement there.
